content:
Sure! A common example of a complex verb conjugation in Punic is the verb "to love," which is written as "𐤀𐤅𐤊𐤍". Here is an example of its conjugation in the imperfect tense, which is a tense that refers to ongoing or repeated actions in the past:

- 1st person singular: 𐤀𐤅𐤊𐤍𐤏𐤕𐤓 (ani 'ahibu)
- 2nd person singular: 𐤀𐤅𐤊𐤍𐤏𐤔𐤌𐤕 (anta 'ahibīš)
- 3rd person singular (masculine): 𐤀𐤅𐤊𐤍𐤏𐤔𐤆𐤓 (hu 'ahibən)
- 3rd person singular (feminine): 𐤀𐤅𐤊𐤍𐤏𐤔𐤌𐤆𐤓 (hi 'ahibatən)
- 1st person plural: 𐤀𐤅𐤊𐤍𐤏𐤔𐤕𐤌𐤕 (na'ahibīn)
- 2nd person plural: 𐤀𐤅𐤊𐤍𐤏𐤔𐤌𐤔𐤌𐤕 (ʔantān 'ahib-nu)
- 3rd person plural: 𐤀𐤅𐤊𐤍𐤏𐤔𐤆𐤌𐤔𐤌𐤕 (hum 'ahib-nu)

As you can see, the verb conjugation in Punic is quite complex and includes not just the verb root, but also suffixes and prefixes that change depending on the subject and tense.
